userreviews.userReview: There's no other literary personage like Joyce Carol Oates. She is a piece of work like Joan Rivers; she is classy like a British Lady; she is like some uber-conscientious (not to mention less literal) S. King. She is prolific; her work thrills & entrances... she cares for her sentences like adorable puppies, and like adorable puppies she beats them sporadically into discipline, too. She is ruthless. She is flawless-- a Reader's Writer, through and through (which, any reader must attest, is an essential and absolute MUST).Marya has all the elements that made "Blonde" my favorite book this year... a woman's life is complex, despite fame, fortune, or brains bestowed upon her by higher forces. Marya comes from miserable beginnings and she suffers everlasting misogyny (and not just from men)--of course being meek, she evolves into the successful woman of letters we would imagine, yet still remains an intriguing introvert. And thank goodness we have Super(Writer)-Woman herself to give us access to such tortured & multidimensional souls.

I gave it 3 stars based on Joyce Carol Oates' mastery of the English language and her ability to delve deeply into the complexities of human behavior. I found myself rooting for Marya throughout the first half of the story. However, Marya's academic life, particularly the period following her first couple of years in college, is pedantic, a real challenge to read. It took me 3 days to get through the final 100 pages! The sad part of this is that by the end of the book, I no longer empathized with this eccentric character. Oates successfully managed to turn off any positive feelings I still harbored. Too bad.

Marya's life is described in chapters dealing with a traumatic childhood, religious observations, college experiences, a career in academia, and relationships. Throughout it all, the overwhelming feeling is one of loneliness and a life lived searching for a sense of belonging. The chapter dealing with thoughts on religion reminded me of Flannery O'Connor. The abrupt ending, although disconcerting, is probably intentional. I think this book is brilliantly written, and perhaps gives us more of an insight into JCO as a person than most of her fiction.

2.5 stars... I loved this book and I also hated it so I guess I liked it, sort of. The beginning captured my attention and I was hooked. The ending was also good. However, there were times that I was completely bored and skimmed over the words, almost quitting. Then it would get good again. I did love Marya though. I wanted her to escape her early life and was happy that she was so successful in the education and career. Her relationships with men drove me crazy, always married men. She was too smart for that and it bothered me but she was young I guess...By the end of this book, I really just wanted it to be over.

This book is incredibly well written, as all of Joyce Carol Oates' books are. Marya is a very unique character whose life you become absorbed in. However, the book was profoundly depressing, and I spend my life reading depressing books so that's saying a lot. From the first to the last page, Marya's life is horrendous and everyone she loves dies or abuses her in some way. I read somewhere that there were a lot of autobiographical elements to this book, but I sure hope not for Oates' sake. A good book, but not a beach read.

Years ago I used an excerpt from this novel (it was excerpted in a St. Martin's textbook) in a comp course I was teaching and was amazed by the layers of the story (when Marya is a student at Port Orskenay college). Students responded in complex ways to it as well. I heard Oates speak recently and was motivated to finally read the whole novel. For me the novel sags a bit in the "academic" section when Marya is a prof and the ending is abrupt in an unsettling way that I suspect is intentional. But overall I enjoyed it, and I think what it has to say about working class girls going to college is not only historically important but relevant, and perhaps, sadly, becoming even more relevant today.

This is a novel in memoir style. I felt that I knew Marya, but couldn't quite like her or feel comfortable with her. Which is the kind of person she was! A dysfunctional early home life left it's mark on Marya's personality, but determination and her intellectual interests helped her make accomplishments in life that would not be predicted by those who knew her and her background. A good read.

I read this book a long time ago apparently, but only remembered the middle chapter. That might sound like a negative comment, but there's something about this book that makes it shadowy in a nicely haunting way.
This is why people want to give her all sorts of prizes.

https://thebookloversboudoir.wordpres...Marya: A Life starts off really well.I enjoyed the book for the first half, mainly the chapters that detailed her unhappy, traumatic childhood. These sections are well written and Marya is an easy person to connect with and feel empathy for.However, things started to go downhill after the halfway point when focus shifts to Marya’s academic life.I found the pace of the novel changes from this point, becoming slow and long-winded to the point of tedium. The last 100 pages were a slog to get through.Unfortunately, Marya starts to change as well and I found my sympathy for her the trauma she experienced as a child gradually waning. She’s just not a particularly nice person. She’s eccentric as a child and this comes across as sweet. However, as an adult she is cold and prickly and very dislikeable. I appreciate what JCO tried to do with Marya: A Life and her prose is as great as ever but the book doesn’t hold together.
I read this because it is one of Joyce Carol Oates' more personal novels. It has left me with a bit of a knot in my stomach.

Marya's rise from humble beginnings to become a respected academic and writer is an interesting one and this had the potential to be a great book. What marred it for me was the detached style of writing and the slightly pretentious narrator who reflects the overly-cerebral and chilly character of Marya. For much of the time I felt like someone was telling me this story second hand rather than allowing me to experience it for myself.Marya's life is not an easy one and her traumatic childhood can account for many of her flaws, but her sense of superiority gets boring after a while. Maybe this was a protective shield she had to create to forge her own path but even at the end of the book she still believed that her Uncle who raised her surely had to love her more than his own daughter because she was smarter! She does come to realise that you can't escape from the past no matter how hard you try but just when it seems she might experience some real emotional growth, the story ends abruptly.I liked the way this book portrays the struggles of "scholarship girls" whose only outlet from a stifling life of poverty and conformity was through academia. It also shows just how insular and archaic the academic world can be. When Marya leaves this world behind (for reasons we're not privy to) to live in New York and write about human rights abuses in Latin America, there's still a distinct sense that nothing she does really makes much difference. I'm not sure if this was Oates' intention but there's something obscene to me about well-heeled journalists and academics who jet-set from one international conference to another making a very nice living off the suffering of others without doing anything to alleviate it.Another thing that bothered me was the lack of women in the book. All of the important people in Marya's life are brilliant, intellectual men. The only woman she has a significant friendship with is Imogene, who is portrayed as manipulative and fake. Her cousin Alice and the girls she goes to school with are simpletons and her Aunt is an insensitive cow. In an era when so many women were embracing feminism and challenging gender-roles, she doesn't come across a single female who is worth mentioning in detail apart from Imogene. It's only males she's inspired and influenced by so in the end this independent, intelligent and complex woman is defined largely by her relationships with men. Ironic really.I can't help comparing this book with Stoner by John Williams which is about a young man from dirt-poor beginnings who finds an outlet in academia, but who then struggles with faculty politics and his personal relationships in a rapidly changing world. I think Marya would have benefited from some of Stoner's rawness and honesty.

I was pretty frustrated by Marya. The first couple of chapters deal with childhood, adolescence and religion, and I found Marya's quite deliberate obtuse nature pretty irritating. She grows into herself though, and by the time she made it to college I quite liked her. The naivete she displays as she enters an affair with her Professor is touching, and his loss is quite crushing. For me, this was the most magical part of the book - Marya growing into her career, in touch with her passion, riding the coat tails of this gent towards bigger and better things. But then it ends. Marya gets a job, hangs around with a douchebag fellow Professor, has another romance very similar to the Professor one, and ends up alone, isolated, strangely dependent on men she doesn't even seem to like that much. And that's when I realised that almost all of her story and behaviour is driven by men. Is that because of her childhood experiences? Are they her outlet for the pressure of her intellectualism? Is she just lonely? I couldn't really figure it out, and it drove me pretty mad.

As always with JCO one is carried off on the flood of her writing from the first pages. Marya is an odd character though; obviously damaged by her early experiences one nevertheless feels this is the kind of person she would have grown into in any case. As such, although her story is fascinating, she’s curiously unsympathetic - in fact one can well understand her Aunt Wilma’s impatience with her. I had the feeling that by the last third of the book even JCO was losing enthusiasm for her! It’s as though she’s flicking through a photo album of her life, going faster all the time. Marya is said at one point never to have deeply loved anyone – perhaps that’s why the male characters she has relationships with, Feinn, Gregory and Eric, never really come to life. The one person she encounters who’s really convincing is the truly awful Imogene Skillman! Still, some wonderful passages though, including the vivid description of ‘the reading experience’ on pp 146-147; just not among my favourite JCO novels.

Marya's life gives the book its title, and so one might expect a ordinary progression. But the reader being so close to the feelings of the heroine, the plot is less present than a succession of emotional paintings, which give all its splendor to this novel of initiation. Thus, the narration allows the reader not to judge the character, and is not that an important point, a proof of the writer's mastery ? Marya will takes part in my literary memories... La vie de Marya donne son titre au livre, et l'on pourrait donc s'attendre à une progression banale. Mais le lecteur étant si près des sentiments de l'héroïne, l'intrigue est moins présente qu'une succession de tableaux émotionnels, qui donnent toute sa splendeur à ce roman d'initiation. Ainsi, la narration permet au lecteur de ne pas juger le personnage, et n'est-ce pas là une chose importante, une preuve de la maîtrise d'un écrivain ? Marya prendra part à mes souvenirs littéraires...

I love Joyce Carol Oates and have read so many of her novels. To me, some of her more recent works have not been as good as some of her earlier works. I believe this book was written in the 1980s and to me it was Oates in her true style and form. I read reviews where many said they did not like Marya, they could not warm up to her character. To me, that was the point. Marya has issues, you are not really supposed to like her or feel sympathy for her. The issues are not stated outright, but the reader can definitely discern what they are! The only part I did not like was the ending. Even though I think I understood it, i.e. Marya trying to focus on her own likeness in her mother's photo, I thought the ending was rather abrupt.

An intense, successful woman views her life.I chose this book because of the author. Years ago I read many of Joyce Carol Oates books and enjoyed them immensely. Today I find I am not looking for the same type of reading material. In this book she describes the life of a very intense girl growing into a woman. Her life proceeds in anecdotes more than living day by day. It's always as if she can make an interesting story to tell others then she is content for a moment. I would suggest this book for a real intellectual person. It is an interesting cameo of a life but it is not a happy book.

On the one hand, the portrayal of female friendships makes me feel less lonely, because I usually don't connect with other females. On the other hand, I think hasn't this author ever had a single friendship not based on game playing and manipulation? I remember liking this a lot. I read it several times when I lived in Michigan. I'm at the point in my life where I feel I am backed up in terms of reading I should do. I feel more and more guilty whenever I revisit something old. Like I should be reading new stuff all the time to make up for my years of depression and psychic stagnation. Still, I think I might choose this one.

I'm a fan of Joyce Carol Oates but was a little disappointed with this book. It was very well written; Oates is, after all, a master at the writing craft. But I never came to care for the main character, Marya. Her childhood circumstances caused her to be an outsider in the home of her aunt and uncle. This type of situation usually causes me to root for the child navigating significant obstacles, but in this case, it did not. Whether this is because of something lacking in the book or my state of mind when I read it I cannot say. However, this will not deter me from reading more of her books. I've read three or four others and enjoyed them immensely.

Interesting but not captivating. Autobiographical elements. Writing seems uneven with some parts extremely well written and others less so. It has an abrupt ending. The chapters represent discrete periods or segments of Marya's life which, for me, interfered with the story's continuity and cohesion. There was one sentence, referring to Marya, that I thought described Joyce Carol Oates as a writer: “She wanted to convert human pain into human words, she wanted to convert the memory of intense emotion in the past into intense emotion in the present, and to be herself unmoved.”

#1001books #707leftThere was much about Marya's character that reminded me of myself, even some of her experiences were like some that I have had. This drew me in and held my attention, but ultimately the ending let me down quite a bit. I thought Oates took the cop-out approach for it and that bothered me. Was it a good book? Yes. Was it a great book? No, not for me with that ending, in any way that I could see. Perhaps someone who reads more between the lines than I do would disagree, but for myself, I did not care for the way Oates finished Marya's story.

I love the books I've read so far by Joyce Carol Oates without exception. While I didn't particularly like Marya, she was interesting, and for me the story of her life became a real page-turner. I really enjoyed the chapters where she returned to her home town and tried to "find herself" in the changed and modernized landscape. I am going to research further to see if I can get some incite into her fear and suspicion of the black janitor. It was intriguing but I guess I just didn't get it. Oates is a brilliant author, so I suspect not getting it is my failure and not hers.

Great and engaging writing, dark and depressing as can be! It is easy to relate to the main character as a child but I could feel little empathy for the adult. ultimately, it left me feeling.... "So What!" It took me a long time to finish. It is supposed to have autobiographical elements of Carol Joyce Oates life. I can only hope she purposely for some unknown reason left the good parts out because there are none in this book.

2.5 starsi'm confused because I feel like there are pages missing from the ending...I appreciate leaving things unresolved, but this feels like my book is actually incomplete.I would say this is the worst book I've read by joyce carol oates, but she is a great writer so it was still worth the read. marya was hard to identify with because her emotions aren't logical to me, but at times they coalesce with my views of the world and I get her.

I liked but didn't love. Another one of JCO's dark and depressing novels. I seem to do well with her books as I keep on choosing to read her on my own accord. This wasn't half as good as We were the Mulvaneys, or The falls or even The Gravediggers Daughter so I am unsure of why it's on the 1001 books u must read before u die list.

Wished I hadn't bothered with this one. Reminded me so much of other books that were disappointing and had few redeeming features. All the drama of her life felt like a soap opera: difficult childhood, neglected, abused, misunderstood, bullied, blah blah blah... However, I did find her kleptomania rather amusing. So there!

I felt like I needed one more chapter got closure but I loved this book and JCO is a hit or miss for me but I could not put this down. it read so much like a memoir that I often forgot that it wasn't!

a great literary novel by Oates. read this many years ago but it has never left my mind. If you like She's Come Undone by Wally Lamb you will like this one. Contemporary fiction ce tered around a young girl with a troubled past

A character sketch about a smart and determined intellectual fighting her way through the world. This book didn't wow me, and I have to vent here that Oates used the word "comprised" wrong---twice. (Ok, I know it's picky.) But it was an engaging enough read.

I definitely struggled through this book; it's incredibly slow and Marya is hard to like. Oates is working too hard here to sound intellectual, I think, and so Marya feels more like an abstraction and less like a human character.

description: Successful author and famous intellectual Marya Knauer did not always occupy such a secure and comfortable position in life. Her memories of her childhood in Innisfail, New York are by turns romantic and traumatic. The early violent death of her father and abandonment by her mother have left her with a permanent sense of dislocation and loss. After decades apart, Marya becomes determined to find the mother who gave her away. In searching for her past, Marya changes her present life more than she could ever have imagined. Vividly evoking the natural beauty of rural upstate New York, and the complex emotions of a woman artist, Marya: A Life is one of Joyce Carol Oates's most deeply personal and fully-realized novels.
